div.p: Time occupied in Representation – Two Hours.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Scene. – Exterior of Beauclere, an old Castle on Windermere, by Moonlight. Lake in the distance; the lower windows of the castle (L.) are lighted up; the voices of gentlemen dining are heard through half-opened windows.
Mrs. Fitzosborne and Jessie discovered in dinner dress, with “gauze clouds.”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fitzosborne.
sp.p: Dear me, what a while those men waste over their wine!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Do you know, I often wonder what they talk about.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Ah! my dear, we had better not attempt to penetrate that mystery. Depend upon it, their conversation is not half as instructive as ours.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: We generally talk about dress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: So do they – perhaps!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: And horses, I daresay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Yes; the women that wear the dresses, and the women that break the horses.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I daresay they are pulling us to pieces at this moment. I wish it was lady-like to listen! Why do ladies always retire after dinner, and leave the gentlemen alone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: My dear, during dinner many elevating and ennobling reflections occur to them, that we shouldn’t understand, so we mercifully leave them that they may give utterance to their magnificent conceptions, or their teeming brains would burst.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Would Baby Boodle’s teeming brain burst?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: No, Baby Boodle’s brain has plenty of turning room. Whenever he shakes his head, I always expect to hear it rattle!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: How can you speak like that of a man you like?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Do you remember how you snubbed Guy at dinner?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Yes, I did it on purpose.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: How can you speak like that to a man you like? And that man going abroad to-night!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: That’s a very different thing. I love Guy very much, but he must be kept in order. Besides, you snub Baby Boodle!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Yes, but Baby Boodle don’t know it. That’s Baby Boodle’s principal charm.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But Baby Boodle is in love with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (sighing). Yes, he would be. These heavy vacuous, good-natured, gentlemanly dragoons always are. I don’t think I ever completely captivated a really clever man in my life. They all seem afraid of me. Look at Mr. Kavanagh – he’s a clever, bright, shrewd fellow; I long to try conclusions with him, but he won’t cross swords with me.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: You’re too clever for him, dear. You pay him back in his own coin, and he don’t like it. He wants a rose from you, and you give him a thistle. Now that frightens clever men.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: And fascinates donkeys. Perhaps you’re right. At all events it points my moral – never snub a clever man, if you care two pins about him.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Ah, Mrs. Fitzosborne, when will you practise what you preach?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (rises – crosses, L.) When bishops black their own boots on Sunday. No, no, if you want to worry poor Guy, there are other ways of doing it.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: By flirting, for instance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (L. C.) Yes, by flirting, in moderation.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (sits on stool, R. C.). Do you know, between ourselves, I often think that with all my demureness, I have a hidden, secret, undeveloped tendency to flirt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (sits, C.). Do you, indeed? My dear Jessie, in a quiet demure self-contained way, you’re about the most irrepressible little flirt I know.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh, Mrs. Fitzosborne!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Look at Denis Grant, for instance.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh, I never flirted with Mr. Grant! During the week that he has been in England I have seen a great deal of his society, and I like him immensely – he’s such a brave, rough, rugged, manly man – but flirt! why he was Guy’s schoolfellow, and his very dearest friend! Oh, Mrs. Fitzosborne! flirt with Mr. Grant!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Ah, remember, Jessie, you are the first white woman he has seen for six years. Be merciful, dear. (rise.)

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p:
(rise). Merciful! How ridiculous! Why, I’ve only chatted and laughed with him as I’ve done with fifty
others, and you’ve thought nothing of it. The idea of your moralizing on the subject of flirtation! Is it because you’ve never done such a thing yourself?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: No, Jessie. it’s because I’ve done so much of it. I’m an old hand, and I can tell in half-an-hour how much a man can hear. When I embark on a flirtation I do so with my fingers on his pulse, and I stop when I find he’s had as much as is good for him. And talking of people who have had as much as is good for them; here come the gentlemen at last!Enter Kavanagh and Boodle from dining room, through glass door.Well, Mr. Kavanagh, we’ve been expecting you very anxiously. What have you been talking about? Miss Blake says it’s dress.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes, it was dress. Baby Boodle and I have been discussing a very nice point. Having regard to the conformation of Baby Boodle’s face and figure, ought Baby Boodle to wear a tall hat with a narrow brim, and a long beard, or a low hat with a broad brim, and a short beard? That’s the question, and we have agreed to refer it to you.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Nothing of the kind, Mrs. Fitz. We were talking about –

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside). Hush!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Well, perhaps you’re right.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Captain Boodle has devoted about forty years’ study to the outside of his head. I think it would be only fair if he began to think about giving its inside a turn.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Oh, no – I can assure you that – the inside of Baby Boodle’s head –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (sharply). I know what you are going to say – that the inside of Captain Boodle’s head has had a turn already. Wasn’t that it?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (annoyed). Yes – (Aside.) confound the woman! I wish she’d let me finish my sentences. (Aloud.) But Baby Boodle’s anxiety about his personal appearance is a very good sign. He has an empty house to let, and he makes its exterior as attractive as possible in order that –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (sharply). In order that Reason may be tempted to come and take up her abode there. Wasn’t that it, Mr. Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (annoyed). Yes – that is what I was going to say – I was going to add that –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: That at present Reason don’t see it; so he’s going to lay it on thicker than ever. Wasn’t that it, Mr. Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside). Oh! this woman is intolerable! (Crosses, L.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: I thay, Mrs. Fitz, I wish you’d let the inthide of my head alone. I do!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Bravo, Baby, so you do. (Slapping him on the shoulder.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (taking him aside confidentially). I thay – look here – you won’t mind my thpeaking plainly!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Not a bit – if you can!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Just tho; I alwayth like to come to the point.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: My dear Baby, make this a rule – if there is ever any point in any of your remarks, come to it as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Just tho. Well, then, I wish you wouldn’t call me Baby!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Becauthe I’ve only known you about three hourth, and ith a liberty. (Turning away.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
Kavan.
sp.p: Poor Boodle! he hasn’t cultivated the art of repartee.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: No, I haven’t; but then, you thee, I am a well-bred man. (Mrs. Fitzosborne goes up, L. C.) Whenever a person thays an impertinent thing, I conthole myself with the reflection that there’s always a thundering good anthwer to it – if one only knew what it was! (Aside – crosses, L.) I think thath one to me!

div.stage: Exit Boodle, L. – Kavanagh retires up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Isn’t Mr. Kavanagh delightful? Do ask him to join the yachting party!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Shall I? But Captain Boodle!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh, Baby don’t care. He and I understand one another. Now, do.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh, I’ve a great favour to ask of you!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Indeed! Command me in anything.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (R.) In anything?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: In anything that is within my poor powers. (Crosses, C.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Ah, that’s a terrible come-down!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I don’t pretend to universality, Mrs. Fitzosborne. Incomprehensible as it may appear to you, I am only mortal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: And do you really believe that it is necessary to assure society that you are not immortal?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (gallantly). I should if I were Mrs. Fitzosborne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh! I know I don’t look my age. Who does, now-a-days?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh, what a rude thing to have said.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Kavanagh didn’t mean it rudely; did you, Mr. Kavanagh? You thought in your innocence that you were paying me a compliment. Now didn’t you?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I had no intention to be severe. You deserve that I should be, Mrs. Fitzosborne – but when I fight with ladies, my weapon is the sword of mercy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Which has no point! (Aside.) Oh, this man is delightful! He gives one such chances. (Crosses to L.)

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (aside). Oh! don’t, you’ll only make him angry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Angry? Nonsense! he’s delicious.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: His temper is a very bad one, and he’ll soon lose it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: My dear, if it’s a very bad one, the sooner he loses it the better.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside). I can’t stand this woman. (Aloud.) Miss Blake, you said you had a favour to ask of me. If you’ll tell me what it is, I’ll execute it if possible.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: We sail for the Mediterranean in about six weeks. We shall have a spare berth on board, and we shall be so glad if you’ll join us.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside). Whew! Poor Guy – poor little chap! Poor Jessie – poor little girl! I wonder if her uncle knows of this? (Aloud.) Really, you’re very kind. I wish your uncle had told me earlier.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! uncle doesn’t know that I – I mean I have not told him, but I am sure he will be delighted to see you on board.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside). A spontaneous invitation of Jessie’s. Poor Guy! Poor little chap!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (crosses, C.) I’m a very poor sailor, Mr. Kavanagh, and you’ll only be troubled with me on very calm days, if that’s any inducement.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: An inducement! It decides me! Miss Blake, I’ll go with pleasure. (Aside.) Boreas, blustering railer, do your worst! (Goes up.)

div.stage: Enter Guy.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Druce!

div.stage: Enter Druce.

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: . Sir?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Is everything packed?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: . Yes, sir. The dog-cart is being put to, and Mr. Warrington will drive you down to the station.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: All right. (Exit Druce.) Time is nearly up, Jessie!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (with indifference). Is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: When do you start, Mr. Guy?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: We leave Beauclere in half-an-hour! It’s awfully hard lines on a man. What’s the use of garrisoning a great barren worthless rock, like Gibraltar? There’s nothing whatever in it.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: That is a defect that you are sent out to repair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (aside). Come, Mr. Kavanagh, they’ve been quarrelling, and we must give them a chance of making it up before they part. (Takes his arm.)

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Don’t go, Mrs. Fitzosborne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Yes, we must. We are going to rehearse a series of repartees that will astonish you when you hear them.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I don’t meditate my good things, Mrs. Fitzosborne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: No, I’m sure you don’t; quite sure. (Kavanagh bows, very much gratified.) If you did you wouldn’t say them. Come along.

div.stage: Exeunt Mrs. Fitzosborne and Kavanagh, R.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (coming forward with some hesitation). Jessie!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: In half-an-hour I must go. I shan’t see you again for –

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Two months.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And then only for a week.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: That’s all? Dreadful, isn’t it? (Sits, R.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: It is dreadful; but it’s still more dreadful to think how little you care about losing me.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh, I’m sorry to lose you! You’re so – so – so useful.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Useful! (Sits.)

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Yes, it’s pleasant to have someone always at one’s beck and call, and now that you’re going, it may be weeks before I’m able to replace you.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Replace me!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Yes. I really don’t know what I shall do, unless Mr. Kavanagh –

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Jessie, dear old Jessie, you don’t mean that – you’re saying it to tease me – Kavanagh’s a snob, and you know it, dear; I’ve no fear of him.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh takes great pains to say pleasant things to me, and if he has a good memory and is quick at executing commissions, he’ll do very well. Besides, he’s never rude to me.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Have I been rude?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Very!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: All sorts of things.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I won’t, I’m too generous.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Then you’ll forgive me!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh, yes.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And, as soon as I arrive at Gibraltar, I’ll – I’ll send you over the greatest curiosity I can buy as a souvenir.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh, do!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: What shall I send you? A pretty little green monkey?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: A green monkey! Oh, that will be delightful. How kind of you; and whenever I look at it, I shall always think of you.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (delighted at first). You will! (Relapses.) Jessie, you’re very cruel to me, the time is so short and – and it will be so long –

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: So short and so long.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: So long before we meet again. Dear Jessie, I don’t put it well, I know.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: No, you don’t.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I’ve never loved anybody but you. If I had been a devil of a fellow and done this sort of thing very often, I should know what to say and how to say it, and I shouldn’t mean it; but I haven’t and I don’t – and I do – and – and –

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: You must practise with the garrison ladies at Gibraltar, and when you come back, dear, you’ll know how to express yourself coherently.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Jessie, you’re very angry with me for something, and I don’t know what it is; but don’t send me away without telling me that I am forgiven for what I’ve done – whatever it is. I love you more than I can ever love anybody else, and – and tell me, dear, that you forgive me. (Jessie is silent.) Jessie, (Sternly, but struggling with emotion.) I shall begin to think that you’re doing this, in order that you may be able to say that you’ve seen a fellow make a fool of himself. (Rises.)

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (after a pause, suddenly bursts into tears, and throws her arms round his neck). My dear old Guy, I love you with all my heart and soul; I like to tease you; I can’t help teasing you, you do turn so red, but I love you as much as you could possibly wish me to. There, I’ve been a very naughty girl, but you know I don’t mean half I say except when I say this, and then I mean it all, and more than I can put into words. There, I won’t be cruel any more – and – and, oh, Guy, isn’t it worthwhile quarrelling when we make it up again like this?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: . My darling Jessie, I must tell the governor of this before I go.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: He must have guessed it, dear.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: . Yes, but the thing must be done officially. (Crosses, R.) It’s an awkward thing to do; it puts a fellow in such a ridiculous light, but it must be done, I know! I’ll put it off to the very last minute, and then he can’t blow me up.

div.stage: Enter Denis, crossing from L. U. E. down R.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (C.) Miss Blake – Mr. Warrington has been looking for you. May I take you to him? He’s in the billiard room.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (crosses, C.). No – no, let her go alone, she knows her way. Stop here with me, I want to speak to you; and, I say, Jessie – (Taking her aside.) break the ground for me if you can. (Exit Jessie.) At last we are alone together, for the first time for six years.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (R. C.) Yes; when I saw you last, you wore a blouse, and a belt with a buckle as big as a blue book.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And you had just thrown out a pair of tails, and precious proud you were of them! and a pair of whiskers, and precious proud you were of them! I remember how I envied them, and wondered if I should ever have any like them. I don’t believe I ever shall! Why, I haven’t seen you since the day you left old Mortiboy’s!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: No. I’ve lived so long away from what people call the world. During the few years that intervened between my leaving school and sailing for Africa I only had one idea in my head – poor little Florence. Ah! well, never mind that; and when she threw me over I couldn’t stand it any longer, and I sailed for Africa the day she married.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (rises). Poor old Den! But you’ve got over that.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes. (Crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Quite?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Quite!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: True?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Grip! (They shake hands – then burst out laughing.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: By Jove! our old school words, when we pledged our honour – I had forgotten them; to think of that cropping up of itself as naturally as if we were still at old Mortiboy’s. They always said of Den Grant that he never went from his grip, and you never did, old boy.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p:
Well, I was going to tell you something – a secret – but not now, I want it to be complete before I tell you – and – and – it isn’t quite complete; I’ll go and finish it up, it only depends upon the governor. Whew! It wants making up
one’s mind to it, though! there, I am screwed up now, but it’s a twister, Old Den, I can tell you. (Exit Guy, L. U. E.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Poor little Flo! Benson turned out a scoundrel, I hear, and she’s teaching music now. It’s strange how easily we get over these things. If any man had told me when she married Benson, that in six years, I could have brought myself to think of Flo Grannitt without a wet eye I’d have knocked him down. And now, perhaps, I’m going through it all again. No, no; Jessie is not playing with me, I won’t think that possible, but I’ll find out to-night. (Exit Denis, R.)

div.stage: Enter Grouse, L. U. E., meeting Druce.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: My friend, are you the butler?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Butler! don’t you see my livery?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Well, what are you?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: I’m Mr. Guy Warrington’s regimental servant.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: So you know Mr. Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: I’ve heard of such a party.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Is he dining here to-night by any accident?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: No, he appeared to be doing it on purpose.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Then he is here! Can I see him?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: (looking round). No, I don’t think you can; but you know best.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Don’t prevaricate, sir.

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Prevaricate! I don’t know what that is; but it don’t sound like the sort of thing I’m likely to do. Seldom do anything over three syllables, sir!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Look here – I’m a lawyer, and I must see Mr. Kavanagh!

div.stage: Enter Boodle, L.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: What’s this?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I’m a lawyer, sir, and I wish to see Mr. Kavanagh on important business.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (to Druce). Bai Jove! Tell Mr. Kavanagh his solicitor wants him.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (crosses, C.). Not his solicitor, sir, Mr. Kavanagh’s solicitor is a chancery – I’m a criminal!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: A what? (Aghast.)

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: A criminal lawyer, sir. Mr. Kavanagh wouldn’t put his affairs into the hands of a criminal.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: No; I should think not! But I say – a criminal?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Yes, sir, a criminal lawyer.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Bai Jove! But I thay, more criminal than other lawyerth.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: My practice, sir, is almost exclusively confined to crime.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Bai Jove! But I thay, what have you done, and ain’t you ashamed of it?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Ashamed of it, sir? I glory in it! (Goes up – sits, C.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Bai Jove! Here’s a hardened thcoundrel, Druth. (Crosses, R. C.)

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: (R.) Sir?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Tell Mr. Kavanagh.

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Yes, sir – beg pardon – shall I send for a constable, sir?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: No; I’ll look after him. It will amuthe me.

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Well! I have heard of honest lawyers, but here’s a lawyer honest enough to own that he’s a thief. He must be a beginner. (Exit Druce, R.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Well, Mr. –

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Grouse – well known at the Old Bailey and Middlesex Sessions.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yes, I’ll be bound you are! Well, Mr. Grouse, you puzzle me.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I should say, sir, from the look of you, that you’re the sort of gentleman that is easily puzzled.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Bai Jove, you’re right. I am! you’re quite right. Thath doothid good. He thaw it at a glance. Now, hereth a fellow with a power of observation much above the average, and talenth that I dare thay would do honour to any respectable calling he might thoothe to adopt, wandering at liberty about a gentlemanth groundth at ten o’clock at night, proclaiming to everybody he comes acroth that he’th a criminal and glorieth in it.

div.stage: Enter Kavanagh.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (C.) Druce says I’m wanted. Who’s this?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (rise). If you mean me, sir, I’m a lawyer, and I want to see you on very pressing business. If you mean him, sir, he’s a lunatic, and ought to be looked after!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Why, Boodle, he’s read you off like a book. (To Grouse.) If you’ll step into the dining room, I’ll hear what you have to say. (Grouse going to house.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (aside to Kavanagh). Don’t let him into the houthe. He’s a criminal, he thays tho.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Fact!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I’ll hear what you have to say here.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: But not before him.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Oh, I’ll go – (Aside to Kavanagh.) and send for a constable.

div.stage: Exit Boodle, R.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Now then, what is it?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: My name is Grouse, sir, of Grouse and Cookit, Thavie’s Inn. I’ve come, sir, on a very melancholy errand, sir! Poor Miss Blake, sir, orphan, sir!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well, what of that?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I feel for an orphan, sir. I’m an orphan, sir.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Your parents are in luck.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (piously). I trust so, sir, I trust so. Well, sir, I bring bad news about Miss Blake, very bad news. Bear up, sir, it’s a blow, but bear up.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well, what is this about Miss Blake?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Well, sir, she inherited her fortune of twelve thousand pounds through her father dying intestate at Cadiz, where he was in practice as an English solicitor. (Crosses, C.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Well, her father ain’t her father. He adopted her when she was twelve months old, and having brought her up as his daughter, never had the heart to undeceive the pretty little gal – and when he died, suddenly two years ago, she succeeded to his fortune as a matter of course. Bear up, sir, it’s a blow, and it’s coming, but bear up.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: But if Jessie Blake is not Blake’s daughter, his estate should go to his next of kin, and that is –

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: You, sir! (Kavanagh sits, R.) Bear up, sir, it’s a blow, but bear up.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Why did you not mention this at the time of Mr. Blake’s death?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Why should I, sir. The pretty little girl was an orphan, and I didn’t know that Mr. Blake had any relations. I held my peace. Well, I learnt only last week that he had a nephew alive. Well, then I didn’t care. The pretty little gal was an orphan all the same. But when I learnt that that nephew was an orphan too, my heart yearned towards him, and I said, “Now,” says I, “it’s orphan against orphan, and let the best orphan win!”

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: You’ll want to be paid I suppose? Besides your costs out of pocket, what do you want?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: The orphan, sir, has twelve thousand pounds. I don’t believe I could bring myself to disinherit her on any terms short of snacks.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Snacks?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Half-and-half.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (rises). Why you inf –. If you have evidence of this it appears to me that I could compel you to produce it, and punish you for having concealed it.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p:
Could you, sir? You know more about these
things than I do, and I’m always glad to learn. How, sir?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: By searching the registers throughout the country till I find out all about her.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: That would be a capital plan if you knew the young lady’s name, sir; but you don’t. (Kavanagh crossing, L.) And if she was born in Great Britain or Ireland: but she wasn’t.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: And if you fail to prove all this?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I shall be satisfied with the consciousness that the scattering of these here shiners, will be in the hands of an orphan whichever way it goes.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well, I’ll agree, provided that my liability is contingent on the recovery of the property. But what shall I have to do?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I’m off to Cadiz, to-morrow. You must join me there in six weeks to establish your claim before the local courts. But in the first place, you must go to town and see my partner – there’s his card (Giving card.) – and enter into the necessary arrangements. He won’t be hard on you. He’s an orphan too.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: All right. I’ll see to it.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Good evening, sir.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Mind, you take your chance!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Yes, sir, the satisfaction of feeling –

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Exactly – of course. Virtue’s its own reward.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Indeed, sir! how do you know?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: How do I know? Because, you scoundrel, vice requires to be so devilish well paid for its dirty work, that it swops up all the profit.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: So it does, sir. We divide the profits. Good evening. (Exit, R.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p:
Jessie Blake not old Blake’s daughter. Oh, it’s a lie! But what object could that fellow have in coming all the way down here if his story is false? Twelve thousand pounds to share with him! Poor Jessie! Well, I want it more than she does. I eat more – I drink more, a good deal more. I do everything more that costs money! (Sits, C.) She can easily retrieve her position; she can make a fortune by teaching music – I can’t. She can live on her relations – I can’t. She can marry Guy Warrington – I can’t. Hollo! here’s the noble savage –Enter Denis, R. L. E.“Lo! the poor Indian whose untutored mind,” and so forth. Well, Denis, my boy, you don’t look happy. Are you pining for the dusky Tippety-wee, the oily daughter of the great
chief Rum Fusti Bang; or does that mighty body fret at having to pack itself into a tight dress suit? Which is it?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I say Mr. –

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Kavanagh!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Kavanagh, why do you say such rude things to me?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Rude? That’s not rudeness, my boy, that’s chaff – repartee, and so on.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Repartee? What’s that?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: The art of –

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: The art of saying out loud what well-bred people only think!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well, that’s repartee in its roughest state. If I call you a noble savage, and you say to me “Kavanagh” you’re a “snob,” that’s repartee in its simplest and most obvious form.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: And on that account particularly adapted to the use of a beginner, like myself.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Exactly. But if I say, when you approach me, “Lo! the poor Indian, whose untutored mind,” and you reply –

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: That the person who calls a man an Indian, because he has travelled in Africa, is hardly an authority on the subject of tutorship?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (taken aback). Precisely – that’s repartee in its highest state of cultivation. That’s the sort of thing you’ll get to in time. In the meanwhile –

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: In the meanwhile you won’t quarrel with me if I conduct myself in the simpler and more obvious form. (retires up, R.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Damn the fellow! (Aloud) I tell you what it is, Mr. Denis Grant –

div.stage: Enter Jessie, L. 1 E .

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: What is it, Mr. Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: It is this, Miss Blake – I’ve been giving Mr. Grant a lesson in repartee – at present he’s a beginner, and handles his weapon clumsily. (Crosses, L.) I will give him another lesson at an early opportunity. (Exit Kavanagh, L. 1 E .)

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (delighted) Have you been snubbing Mr. Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Well, yes, I couldn’t help it, he brought it on himself.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! I’m so glad. I like to see him taken down. I hope you were very rude to him!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p:
Well, I’m afraid I was. (Goes, R.) I’m rather a rough
customer, and I’m afraid I’ve lain by too long, and grown too rusty to take a polish now.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! I wouldn’t have you polished for worlds. (Sits, R.) We don’t French polish oak trees!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (foot on bench). But oak must be polished before it is entitled to take rank as drawing-room furniture.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: And do you aspire to take rank as furniture? Does the grand mighty massive living oak aspire to be chopped up into chairs and tables?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: If the living oak can serve you better in that form than any other –

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But it can’t. It can best serve me by spreading its great boughs over me, and by letting me sit at its foot, and wonder at the folly of those who would plane down its rugged bark, and cover its leaves with a double coat of green paint. Why, what a First Commissioner you’d make!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (door, R.). I’m not propounding my own views, but those of the society in which you move. I’m over-matched in England. It’s coarse barbaric power against culture and civilization.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Nonsense! It’s a primeval forest against a furniture shop! Now, once for all, I won’t have you chopped up into chairs and tables – you’ll only suffer for it in the long run. Look at Captain Boodle, he’s as good a fellow as ever lived, but he’s chopped himself up into a chair, and see how Mrs. Fitzosborne sits on him. Well, have you nothing to say? (Takes his arm.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (R.).I’ve a great deal to say, but I don’t know how to begin.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (walking, R. C.). Begin at the beginning.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: But if the beginning should prove to be the end?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Begin again at the end, and try back to the beginning.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: You give me courage.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Then you should be ashamed to take it from me, I have so little. Why I’m afraid of a frog! Are you afraid of a frog?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: No, but I am of a woman! Are you afraid of a woman?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Not of any woman I ever saw. But you don’t mean to say you’re afraid of me?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (after a pause). No, I am not afraid of you. I – I have no reason to fear so tender, and merciful a little lady!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (alarmed – aside). Merciful! Mrs. Fitzosborne’s own word!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p:
(sits, C.). We men are strange contradictions. When
we risk a few hundred pounds, we place it in the hands of an attorney. When we enter on a matter in which the stakes are happiness against misery, hope against despair, life against death; we take our destiny, and place it in the hands of an inexperienced child!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But at whose mercy have you placed such a stake?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (passionately). At yours, Jessie! I have thought over five hundred ways of saying this; but what I have to say will not be controlled by forms of speech. I have lain awake at night turning my meaning into set words, but it breaks its bonds, and declares itself in its own rough untutored way. I am a plain, rugged, earnest man. I have loved but once before; if you send me away from you, I shall never love again.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Grant, I am very sorry for this – very, very sorry. I had no idea of it; I have been warned that I should bring you to this, but I did not believe it – I am such a child! And this night of all others! Mr. Grant, forgive me! I have been thoughtless, but not wicked – I liked you so much more than any of the others – I mean than any of those who were stopping here – and then you were his schoolfellow, and you have been so good to him! And, oh! Mr. Grant, I thought you knew – I thought you knew! (Takes both his hands as if about to speak.) Mr. Grant, I – I – cannot tell you! (Bursts into tears.)

div.stage: Enter Guy, hurriedly, prepared for journey – Jessie attempts to go.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Don’t go, Jessie; you must stop; I’ve seen the governor, and it’s all right. I want Den to see how thoroughly swamped with happiness I am; so he must look at you and hear of you at the same time, or he won’t appreciate the full beauty of my position.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Let me go, Guy; you can tell him without me.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Tell him? I’m not going to tell him. He shall hear it from you.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I can’t, Guy – indeed, I can’t.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (quietly). Tell me, Miss Blake.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (reluctantly). I – I – am engaged to be married to Guy.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p:
There, my dear old Den! – What do you think of that? Haven’t I done well for a fellow of eighteen? (Crosses, C.) You couldn’t have done as much, she wouldn’t have had you, you great gruff, surly bear! You’ve had her all to yourself for a week, and ought to have cut me out, but you
haven’t! Not you. Triumph of the slight but civilized Briton over the massive but untutored savage! Tableau! (Stands in an attitude of triumph, with Jessie in his arms.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Indeed, I wish you a happy life together, Jessie! (Jessie crosses, C.) I may call you Jessie? (Taking her hand.)

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh, yes.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Jessie, I am happy to think that you will live in the care of so good and true a fellow as my dear old friend, Guy Warrington. God bless you! (Kisses her.) I did – I did not know of this.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (C.). Then you’re a blind old mole. Why, it’s been going on – how long has it been going on, Jess?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (C.) I don’t know.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Well, strictly speaking, it’s been going on about sixteen years, but it only began to look like business about six months ago.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (R.). Six months? As long as that? (Aside) Poor Guy!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Jessie, dear, in five minutes I must be off; tell Mrs. Fitz I should like to say good-bye to her – I want to speak to Den for one moment. (Exit Jessie, R. 1 E .) (Guy changes his manner to one of great earnestness.) Denis, you see that girl, she is life and death to me; I am dreadfully uneasy at leaving her – she – she is the best girl in the world, but she has no mother, and my father don’t understand her – and – and she has one fault – she – she is a little bit of a flirt. You wouldn’t think so, to look at her, would you?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (bitterly). No, not to look at her!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: She means no harm, it’s high spirits and nothing more, but men misunderstand her; and I’m dreadfully absurdly jealous, I know, but I can’t help it. It would keep me awake all night, if I thought there was no one to look after her, and tell her when – when she has gone far enough. Denis, I’m only a boy, but I love her so dearly that I would kill myself if she forgot me! Will you look after her while I am away? Will you keep her straight in my interests? Will you watch over her, and protect her from such dangers as if she were to be your own wife? Promise me this, by our old school friendship.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: By our old school friendship I promise it.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Thank you, Den, I shall go away quite happy.

div.stage: Enter Jessie, R., Kavanagh, L., Mrs. Fitzosborne and Boodle, R.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well, Guy, off at last to fight the Paynim foe?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p:
No, I’m not going to fight any foe! I’m going to
garrison, a confounded dull old rock for five shillings and threepence a day. I’m only a sub, Mr. Kavanagh, and I can’t get up a war for your amusement; and if I could I wouldn’t. But if ever I’ve the misfortune to have to go into an action, I believe I shall behave like a gentleman. Good bye, Mrs. Fitz, don’t be too hard on Boodle. Good bye, Baby. Mr. Kavanagh, I don’t mind your chaff, let’s shake hands on it. Denis, old man, good bye. Jessie, good bye. (Kisses her – then going, returns suddenly.) Oh, Jessie my love, never mind them; (To the others.) We are parting for a long time, and you’d do so too. (Embraces her passionately.) Denis, you remember your promise?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And you’ll keep it?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: True?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Grip!

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Scene. – On board Mr. Warrington’s Yacht off Cadiz. Mainmast and portion of mainsail forming wing, R.; portion of forsail forming wing, L.; cabin gangways, R. and L.; skylight, C. Morning.
Mrs. Fitzosborne and Boodle discovered; Mrs. Fitzosborne reading – Boodle, lying on his back on some rugs, smoking.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: This yacht-life is awfully jolly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: It’s awfully slow.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Ith the same thing. On thore, the world’th fatht and gets a-head of me. At thea, the world’th thlow and keepth alongside of me. The world and I get on very well in a yacht. I thould be thorry to leave the world in a yacht. I’m afraid my remarkth fail to interetht you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Yes, they bore me.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: You’re very good. They uthed to amuthe you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: They amuse me still when you’re serious. I can laugh at your sentiment, but your jokes are too solemn.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Nothing could be fairer than that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh, Baby Boodle, what a donkey you are!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yeth, I’ve heard the remark before.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: . They may well call you Baby!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yeth, it’th a pretty name. There’th a very remarkable thircumthtance connected with that name. Curiouthly enough, I wath firtht called “Baby” when I was quite a little child. It’th wonderful how they hit off my character even then. It wath me all over. Hullo! what’th thith? (Kicking a portmanteau.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh’s luggage.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: The doothe! Then he’th come on board.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: He joined last night from Cadiz.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Where ith he?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Below. I wish he’d come on deck.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Tho’ do I. He’th a thnob and you thnub him and I like it. I thnub him too, but you thnub him better than I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Not at all. It’th a great lark to thee you and Kavanagh together, and ath we must have him and can’t help ourselves; ith doothid lucky you’re on board to take him down. Here he ith. Now go in at him.

div.stage: Enter Kavanagh, L.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (changing her manner). Oh, Mr. Kavanagh, I’m so delighted to see you.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: I am indeed. Now that you’ve joined we shall have such fun.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: You’re very good to say so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh, no! Indeed I mean it.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (aside). Wait a bit. He’ll catch it presently.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Three weeks’ yachting have blunted my faculties. Everybody is so stupid on board, and I’m glad you’ve come, because I want you to sharpen them for me.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Really, Mrs. Fitzosborne, that sounds like a compliment!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Does it? I like a man who’s easily pleased.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: It’th coming, I don’t know what it is, but it’th coming!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well, when you admit that it is in my power to sharpen your blunted faculties –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: I credit you with all the brilliant qualities of a knifeboard! There – I’m better after that! (Sits.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Ith come! He’th got it! I didn’t know what it wath; but I knew it wath coming.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (hurt). I recognise the bluntness of which you complain. If it is in the power of a knifeboard to –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: To impart point and polish to my remarks, you will be only too happy to serve me in that capacity. Wasn’t that what you were going to say, Mr. Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well – yes. (Aside.) Confound the woman, I wish she’d let me finish.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: You’re too hard on him, Mrs. Fitz. Whenever Mr. Kavanagh hath a poor little thquib to dithcharge you alwayth take the bang out of it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh handles his squibs so awkwardly that he would certainly burn his fingers with them if I didn’t take them out of his hands and finish them for him.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: That’s another; nothing could be fairer than that!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh, Baby Boodle, do go and get your breakfast while it’s calm.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: I was only backing you up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Thank you, but I’m quite equal to meeting anything Mr. Kavanagh can say without assistance.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: He’s getting it all over him. (Aside.) Don’t spare him; he’s bad form – he’s got no friends. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Now that foolish fellow has gone, let’s begin. Are you fond of yachting?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Sometimes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: In fine weather?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: No, in good company. In yachting, one’s enjoyment depends so much less on oneself than on one’s companions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: You are quite right not to depend too much upon yourself.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes. I may be hypercritical, but I am tired of myself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: You see you have had so much of yourself.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: No doubt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: But there, I won’t be rude any more, I’ll say a pretty thing to you. I’ll admit that if your epigrams and repartees amused you as much as they amuse others, you would never tire of your own society.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (with an elaborate bow). Thank you, Mr. Fitzosborne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: But they don’t, do they!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: No they don’t, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: You see you’ve heard them so often before! (Aside.) This man does give one such chances!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: At all events I may conclude from your admission that they amuse you, that you have not heard them before.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: No, indeed! the society in which I move is so horribly well-bred. I can forgive almost any rudeness if it’s clever.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Then I may conclude that I am forgiven?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (R. C.). I have nothing to forgive so far – you have been neither rude nor clever.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (L. C., annoyed). If you don’t take care I am afraid I shall certainly be one of those two things. (Crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Yes, I know which.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I am afraid I shall be rude.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (R. and L.). Yes, that’s what I meant. It’s wonderful how you smart people wince under the operation of your own weapons when they are turned against you!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Why not! A surgeon would gladly cut off both of my arms if necessary, but –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: But he would expostulate if you were to retaliate, by cutting off both of his –? Wasn’t that what you are going to say?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes, if you had permitted me to finish my sentence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: If you were to cut off both his arms?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: After he had cut off both of yours?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes, at least – that is –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Don’t apologise for him. Under the circumstances his astonishment would be excusable!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Mrs. Fitzosborne – once for all I must protest –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Why you don’t mean to say that you are getting angry?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I’m very much afraid I am. (Crossing, C.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh, but that won’t do at all. Jessie expressly invited you to relieve the tedium of the voyage.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Did she? Are you quite sure?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Quite sure.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Then I’m very sorry for our young military friend.(Shaking her hand.)

div.stage: Enter Boodle, from cabin.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: They’ve had a row, and they’re making it up. Mrs. Fitz, the letter bag has arrived. Here are two letters for you, one for me – (Looks at it.) Tailor, eh? Good-bye. (Throws it into the sea.) Nothing could be fairer than that. One for you. (To Kavanagh.) And now, Mrs. Fitz, breakfast is ready.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh, I don’t want any breakfast!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside). From Grouse, eh? Now, what the deuce can Grouse want? I only left him yesterday.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (aside to Kavanagh). I shall keep a chair for you, next to mine. After breakfast we will renew the subject – but not a word yet.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: The steward tells me there’s a first-rate devil waiting for us below.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Captain Boodle, I’m quite sure of that. (In affected astonishment.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: No, no; when I thay a “devil,” of courth I mean a grill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (relieved). Oh, well, you’re not the first man who has mistaken cause for effect!

div.stage: Exeunt Boodle and Mrs. Fitzosborne into cabin.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Now, here’s a letter from Grouse, eh? Very good! Now, before I open this, let me see how the coast lies. Jessie seems to have taken a violent fancy to me. She invites me of her own free will to join this yachting party; and commissions her friend to let me understand that Jessie is to be had for the asking. Now, if I marry Jessie, I can dispense with Grouse altogether, for her money will, in that case, be mine, or as good as mine. Good-bye, Grouse! The connection is humiliating; I’ll have nothing more to do with him; I’ll return his letter unopened. Stop a bit! The worst of returning a letter unopened is that you never know what’s in it. Steward!

div.stage: Enter Steward, L.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Place some boiling water in my cabin.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p: Yes, sir! (Exit Steward.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: There are ways of returning a letter unopened after you have mastered its contents, especially when it’s enclosed in an adhesive envelope. (Exit, L.)

div.stage: Enter Jessie and Boodle, from cabin.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! what a lovely morning, Captain Boodle!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yeth, pretty well. It wath until you came on deck.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (sits, L. C.). Indeed? I haven’t noticed any change.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p:
Bai Jove! But no you wouldn’t, becauthe you are alwayth with yourthelf, you thee; you don’t think of it at the time, but you are. Now, with other fellowth, ith different. If a man wath alwayth bethide you – if he had the happineth of being alwayth bethide you – he wouldn’t notith any change.
I am not alwayth bethide you, but you alwayth are bethide yourthelf! (Aside.) That contains a very pretty thentiment, though ith moth awkwardly put.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Then you really mean to say that my bright presence on deck makes everything else dull by contrast!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (rises). Thath it! Thath what I wanted to thay! Everything! Everything, Mith Blake, exthepting me, and it politheth me up into thuch a thtate of fireworkth that I hardly know myself. Now, I don’t go off like thith when I’m alone.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But there’s Mrs. Fitzosborne – you say all sorts of good things to her, don’t you?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (sitting on deck – confidentially). No – thath the truth. No. She takth me down. Whenever I open my mouth the alwayth hayth, “Oh! Baby Boodle, what a donkey you are.” Ith doothid thmart of her; but nothing makth me feel so like a donkey as telling me I am one. Don’t you feel that yourthelf?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (laughing). Oh, invariably! (Rises.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Now, I believe I could talk to you for ever!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! Captain Boodle!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: I could – if you would let me.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! I should only be too happy! But what would Mrs. Fitzosborne think?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Oh, thee wouldn’t care; thee’s got Kavanagh to amuthe her. She hates Kavanagh, and she thnubs him; I thnub him too, but I don’t thnub him as well as thee does. Kavanagh acts upon her as a red rag acts upon a bull. I believe she’d toth him for a penny.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Toss him for a penny?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yeth. I mean she’d gore him. I don’t mean headth and tailth – and yet I do mean headth and tailth, when you come to think of it! Ha, ha! nothing could be fairer than that! Hallo! here ith the noble thavage.

div.stage: Enter Denis from the cabin, R.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Captain Boodle, Mrs. Fitzosborne wants you below. Don’t go, Jessie.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But I wish to go.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I want to speak to you seriously. Come, give me carte blanche to say what pleases me.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I’ll give you carte blanche to say what pleases me. Our tastes are so different that I’m afraid we shall not agree on any other condition.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Ah! But this is not a question of taste.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Then I shall be happy to hear what you have to say on it. (Sits on skylight, C.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Well, then – it’s the old story. I don’t think you are treating Guy fairly.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Yes; I knew it was that.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Ah! conscience, Jessie!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Conscience? Nonsense – experience!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Experience?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Yes, of you. You never speak to me on any other subject. It’s your invariable theme – my constant oblivion of Guy. (Rising and crossing, R.) I am going to him as quickly as the yacht will take me. What more can I do? It isn’t my fault that the Skylark don’t make more way. Oh! you are unreasonable to blame me because the Skylark don’t make more way!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Nonsense, Jessie, I blame you because you flirt with Captain Boodle.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But I can’t help it. He’s such a goose. Now you must admit that he’s a goose.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: By all means, but that doesn’t seem to meet my objection. Put it in this way: would you talk to Captain Boodle as you do if Guy were present?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I don’t know. If Guy were present, I should talk to him.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (C.). Well, Jessie, it’s impossible to talk rationally to you!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (R.). You certainly have not been talking rationally to me!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: You must know that I am only asking you to do what is right.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: You must know that I am not likely to do what is wrong.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I know you are likely to do what is thoughtless and giddy, and what is liable to be misrepresented by meddling ill-natured people.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Evidently, Mr. Grant. (Curtseying.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (after a pause). Jessie, I think you will allow that if I had been actuated by the motives of a mere busybody, I should scarcely pursue my theme after that remark.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: It was with the view of discouraging you that I made it. (Crosses, L.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: But I am not to be discouraged. I love that boy very dearly. I have sworn that I will keep watch and ward over his interests, and at the risk of forfeiting your regard, I will keep my word.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p:
Mr. Grant, your want of familiarity with the usages of society may hold you excused up to a certain point. Let
me tell you that you have reached that point, and if you presume to overstep it, we are strangers. (Going, but returns.) Denis, you make me say things that I am sorry for afterwards; but I have a quick temper, and it is not pleasant to be misrepresented. Forgive me if I have been unkind, but – but – I don’t mean any harm; and – and – Captain Boodle is such a goose – and – and you can’t think I care for him – and (Coldly.) if you please I prefer to be trusted. (Denis stands for a moment, then bows, and exit, R.) (Sitting on ladder.) It’s very hard, I’m sure I’m as fond of Guy as I can be; and, if I do flirt, nothing comes of it, except a pleasant half hour instead of a dull one. Guy likes me to be happy; he told me before he went away to try and be happy, and not fret for him; and I have tried to be happy, and I haven’t fretted for him, and what more can he want? (Wipes her eyes.)

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Fitz from fore-cabin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Jessie, you’re crying!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Am I? Mr. Grant has been lecturing me again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: What a donkey that man is!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: No, no; he means well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Means well! Who doesn’t? I mean well, but I don’t dislocate society in consequence.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But you mustn’t call him a donkey. He is actuated by the best intentions.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: My dear Jessie, the only difference between a donkey with good intentions and a donkey with bad intentions is that one is a good donkey and the other isn’t. What has he been saying to you now?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: He says I flirt with Captain Boodle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Well, so you do.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: But not much, and you don’t mind it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Not a bit, my dear.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: And he don’t mind it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: No, he’s quite resigned.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: And I don’t mind it, and if you don’t mind it, and he don’t mind it, and I don’t mind it, what more can he want? What are you to do on board a yacht? I’m sure I wouldn’t flirt with Captain Boodle on shore.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: No; one must be very much at sea to flirt with Baby Boodle.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: It’s my duty to make myself agreeable to uncle’s guests.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Then why does Mr. Grant interfere? I won’t stand it! (Rises.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Don’t stand it, Jessie. Let him think what he pleases. Flirt with Baby as much as you like. I won’t interfere, and when Mr. Grant remonstrates, admit it all and glory in it.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I will! It’s only fun after all. The idea of supposing that any one who had seen Guy would think seriously for one moment of such a goose as Captain Boodle! Oh! I beg your pardon, dear!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: My dear Jessie, when I first saw Captain Boodle, Guy was about six months old. He was a fine boy, but a grande affaire was out of the question.

sp.speaker: Voice.
sp.p: (from a boat). Yacht ahoy!

div.stage: Enter Boodle, R.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yacht it is!

sp.speaker: Voice.
sp.p: What yacht’s that?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: ’Pon my life I forget! It’th a devilith pretty name I know – the Thky-something. Thky-thail? Here, Jenkins!

div.stage: Enter Sailor, R.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (looks at name embroidered on the man’s Jersey.) Thkylark!

sp.speaker: Voice.
sp.p: Is Mr. Kavanagh on board?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Oh yeth, he’th on board, bleth him! (Boat comes alongside.)

sp.speaker: Voice.
sp.p: Then I’ll come on board!

div.stage: Enter Grouse, on deck – he is very pale, as if sea-sick.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: It’th the criminal!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: It’s the lunatic!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: How are you? Didn’t exthpect the pleathure of theeing you here!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I’m stopping in Cadiz.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: I with you were! Buthineth?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: No, I’m a gentleman at large!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: I know you’re a gentleman, becauthe the Act of Parliament thays tho, and I thee you’re at large, becauthe Cadiz ithn’t a penal settlement. You don’t look well.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I’m not well. It’s the motion of the boat. I want Mr. Kavanagh directly.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (calling down cabin skylights). Kavanagh!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (below). Hullo!

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Fellow to thee you.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: All right. (Exit Boodle, L.)

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p:
(sitting on ottoman, R. C.). Here’s a pretty business! I’ve sent him the letter I meant for Tim Cookit, and if he’s opened it the whole blessed business is blown upon! Here’s
a situation, and I ain’t well! I’m too giddy to think. I might as well be drunk. I’d sooner be drunk. It ain’t a bit more confusing, and it’s much pleasanter!

div.stage: Enter Kavanagh from cabin.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (very coldly). Mr. Grouse, I believe you asked for me?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (aside). It’s all over – he’s read it!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: What is your business with me?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh, I ain’t well, and what I say must be taken without prejudice. I ain’t in a business frame of mind. A office floor is one thing and a lopping sea is another.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Be good enough to come to the point.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh, sir, you got a letter from me?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I did – I received it ten minutes ago!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Sir! Mr. Kavanagh! Sir! Mercy! It was a joke, sir. Look over it, sir.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Look over what?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: The letter, sir! It was my high spirits, sir! I wrote it at sea – in that boat – and when I’m at sea I’m in such spirits. It’s the fresh air, sir; the motion of the boat. It always excites me. You can’t suppose I meant it; I’m not such a scoundrel as that, notwithstanding looks which are against me.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes, you are an unprepossessing person.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Looks ain’t a man’s fault no more than his name is. My looks is bad, but I ain’t a scoundrel. My name’s Grouse, but I ain’t a bird. But look over it.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: . Look over you’re not being a bird?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: No, sir. Look over my having been tempted in a sprightly moment to write that letter. It was the motion of the boat, sir; it always makes me sprightly. And if you could oblige me with a drink of cold water, sir –

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I wonder a knowing attorney like you should indulge in a joke, which, if taken seriously might involve –

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Penal servitude, sir. You’re quite right, and perhaps struck off the rolls into the bargain. But it was all owing to feeling larky on a lopping sea, sir. (Aside.) I’m committing myself! I know I am! If I could only catch him on dry ground I’d come over him in no time. But at sea, he sails all round me!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Grouse, attend to me. You ask me to look over something contained in this letter. What you refer to I don’t know –

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: You don’t know what I refer to?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: I don’t know what you refer to, because the letter is still unopened.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p:
(changing his manner). Ha, ha! Don’t you think I
knew that? Why, I saw it in your hand! I’ll be bound you thought I was in a funk, now didn’t you? (Tries to take it, Kavanagh withdraws it.) Allow me! (Kavanagh makes as though about to open it.) You’ve no call to read it, sir! (Much alarmed.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: It ain’t necessary, sir. I’ll tell you what’s in it. Sir, I implore you to return it. (Aside.) Oh, lor! here’s a go, and I ain’t well!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Do you mean to say that you really wish me to return this letter unopened?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Upon my life and soul I do!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: . Very good. Now, Mr. Grouse, I will return this letter unopened if you desire it; but if I do, I repudiate you and your schemes altogether.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (aside) He can’t! I’ve got him hard and fast! It’s down in black and white, stamped, and all reg’lar. (Aloud.) As you please sir – as you please.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: As to the agreement between us, I require you to destroy it.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Oh, I ain’t got it here, it’s on shore!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Then I will retain the letter until you produce it.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (aside). Damn! (Aloud.) Is that your fixed determination?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: That is my fixed determination! Shall I open the letter? (About to do so.)

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: No – no! (Producing agreement.) It’s too bad – and I’m ill-treated! (Gives him agreement.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Good. (Tears it up, crosses, L.) There is your letter, and you will be good enough to go over the yacht’s side immediately, and not show your face in my presence again. (crosses, L.)

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: But dash it, I’ve gone in for your case to such an extent, that I’m a ruined man if I stop now! Think of my time – think of my clients.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: The county has already provided for them.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: But I shan’t know where to find ’em when I want ’em.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Try Holloway – I mean the prison, not the pills!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Think of my ’elth – broke down in your service.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Try Holloway – I mean the pills, not the prison!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (door, R. C.). Take care, Mr. Kavanagh, I’m an ugly customer on shore!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: You’re no beauty at sea.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p:
So you’ll work this alone, eh? You’ve sucked my brains, and now you’re going to use my information, eh? Very good – now mind, Mr. K., you can’t do without me. If
you get at this here property, I’ve got that as ’ll smash you up, right and tight, whichever way you put it.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: But I am not going to work this alone; I am not going to work this at all.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Not going to work it at all?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: No, I propose to leave the orphan in undisputed possession of her property. Now, go.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (going over the side). Well!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Well, Mr. K., I was going to say one thing, you’re either a blazing liar or a blazing fool! And look here, Mr. K., my only doubt is whether you ain’t both. Good morning. (Disappears over gangway.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: So much for Mr. Grouse! Whew! I feel all the moral elevation of a man who’s done a good action with the additional satisfaction of knowing that virtue is in this case the most paying course. (Takes out pressed copy.) The infernal scoundrel! Fortunately my hand-press was on board, and I’ve taken a facsimile copy of Mr. Tim Cookit’s letter. To think that –Jessie appears R., at cabin gangway.Miss Blake! I’m so glad, so very glad to see you!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: So you’ve joined at last. That’s capital! We’ve exhausted Captain Boodle, and we were looking for you rather anxiously.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: It’s always pleasant to know that one’s arrival has been impatiently awaited.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (rather surprised). Oh! I didn’t say impatiently.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: You said –

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Rather anxiously.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well then, it’s pleasant to think that one’s arrival has been looked for rather anxiously. But may I not say impatiently?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Well – (Aside.) I’ll put in a word for Mrs. Fitzosborne, (Aloud.) Well, yes; I think you may say impatiently by one of us. As for the other –

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Oh! never mind the other.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh! thank you, Mr. Kavanagh.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside) Her friend! (Aloud.) Well, I retract. It was a rude thing to say, but I spoke on the impulse of the moment, and your words gave me such pleasure, that I was carried away by them. You forgive me?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p:
Well, I don’t know – it was very rude indeed – but there I forgive you. (He takes her hand.) I forgive you, Mr. Kavanagh! I tell you I forgive you! (She struggles to free her
hand.) Don’t, Mr. Kavanagh! (Very angrily.) I’m extremely angry with you, sir. I tell you I forgive you!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: And won’t you give me your hand in token of forgiveness?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: No! Won’t my word do?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: It would in England, but off Cadiz, we must conform to the custom of the country.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: And what are the customs of the country?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Well, among other things, recent acquaintance begins by calling one another by their Christian names.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes; in these latitudes, I am Corny, and you are Jessie.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (angrily). Mr. Kavanagh!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: To call you Miss Blake in these latitudes would be an impertinence. It would be as monstrous as if I were to call you Jessie in Westmoreland.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I don’t understand you.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: In these latitudes, people begin with Christian names and get on to surnames when they are on very intimate terms indeed.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Oh, you are joking!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Oh, no; it’s quite reasonable when you come to think of it.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Reasonable?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes, Christian name comes before surname, and new acquaintances begin at the beginning. Its only taking things in their proper order. If we are becalmed here much longer, who knows but that we get on from one thing to another, until I know you well enough to call you Miss Blake.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Never! – I mean always – that is –

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Yes, that is?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I hope we shall not be becalmed any longer. (Crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: And I should be content to be becalmed here for ever – Jessie!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (indignantly). Mr. Kavanagh! Why do you wish to be becalmed here for ever?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (affecting delight). Oh, how kind of you to call me Mr. Kavanagh! in these latitudes! and may I – may I call you Miss Blake?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Of course – I mean no – I – Why do you wish to be becalmed here for ever?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Because every knot the yacht makes will bring me nearer and nearer to absolute desolation. Ah, Miss Blake, I know too well why you are going there, and who awaits your arrival. Gibraltar is a rock on which all my fondest hopes must be inevitably shattered.

div.stage: Mrs. Fitzosborne has entered from cabin, and overheard these words.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Then why go to Gibraltar?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Eh? (Turning round.) I do not go of my own free will, Mrs. Fitzosborne!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Is not that rather familiar?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Familiar?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: In these latitudes. Her name is Emily Fitzosborne. As a recent acquaintance, shouldn’t you begin at the beginning?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Certainly – of course! (Aside.) Confound it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: I should not think you are the sort of man to do anything on compulsion.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Nor am I, Mrs. Fitz – Emily!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: You don’t mind his calling you Emily? He was just explaining that he couldn’t help it in these latitudes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Mind it! It’s the only sensible thing he’s said since he came on board.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: And he says that you must call him Corny!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Only in these latitudes.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Yes, and he says he should be glad if the yacht were becalmed in these latitudes for ever!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (aside to Jessie). That I might call you “Jessie” for ever!

div.stage: Enter Boodle and Denis.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (seeing Denis, hurries away, saying). Mr. Kavanagh, how dare you? (Exit Jessie, R.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: But a perpetual calm would be very monotonous, Corny!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: No fear of perpetual calm when you are on board, Emily.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Emily, eh? Nothing could be fairer than that!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Nonsense, Baby, think of the latitude.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yeth, I am thinking of the latitude: and a pretty considerable latitude it ith! Mrs. Fitz, allow me to offer you my arm. Mr. Kavanagh, I thall have the pleathure of renewing the quethtion of latitude at an early opportunity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Oh! Baby Boodle, what a donkey you are! |(Exeunt Boodle and Mrs. Fitz., L.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Hang it! I hope I’m not going to get into a scrape on her account. Confound her!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (coming forward). Mr. Kavanagh, I want a word with you. I heard you speak to Miss Blake, in a manner which seemed to me to require explanation.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Here’s another! The deuce you did! And may I ask who the devil are you?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Don’t lose your temper – I mean to keep mine.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: It is a matter of supreme indifference to me whether you lose it or keep it. What right have you to demand an explanation?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: None whatever. But I mean to have one, nevertheless.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: The deuce you do!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Look here, Mr. Kavanagh, I speak on the presumption, that I am addressing a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Damn your presumption.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: By all means, if it is an erroneous one. But, if you please, we will assume for the sake of argument that you are a gentleman. You have a fertile imagination, and will have no difficulty in drawing upon it to that extent. Now, sir, I have reason to believe that you are here with the avowed object of winning Miss Blake’s affections. You have still to learn, Mr. Kavanagh, that she is already engaged to be married to your friend Guy Warrington.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (L.) I am fully aware of that fact.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (R.) Ah, you forget; I am assuming for the sake of argument that you are a gentleman. It is on that hypothesis that I say you are not aware that she is engaged to your friend Guy Warrington. In ignorance of that fact you approach her delicately and with diffidence. You are then informed, upon good authority, that her hand is promised to your friend, and you immediately retire and leave him in undisturbed possession of the happiness he has secured for himself.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Do I? You don’t know me!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, I think, I do; but I am assuming – for the sake of argument – that you are a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Assume what you please, but don’t credit me with a magnanimity which is wholly foreign to my nature.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Very well; then I must proceed on a different tack, and I may tell you, that in laying siege to a young lady whom you know to be already engaged, you are behaving like a cad, and in not leaving the yacht after she has plainly indicated to you that your presence is a nuisance, you are in the position of a man who has been kicked and doesn’t mind it. (Goes, R.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Why, man, you must be mad to talk to me in this way? Who the deuce are you? Are you aware that my presence on board this yacht is due to Miss Blake’s express and spontaneous invitation?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (astonished). To Miss Blake’s invitation?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: To her unsolicited and spontaneous invitation – that I am here in the capacity of her declared suitor, and with her full consent.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (after a pause). Mr. Kavanagh, that’s not true!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: What?

div.stage: Enter Jessie and Mrs. Fitzosborne, L.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh! what in the world is the matter?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Miss Blake, Mr. Grant has thought fit to take exception to my presence on board this yacht. I have explained to him that I am here at your express invitation. He tells me that I am telling a lie!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (aside). Don’t stand it, Jessie! Go in at him!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: I will! (To Denis.) Is this so, Mr. Grant?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: It is so, Jessie!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Mr. Grant, let me tell you once for all, that your interference has become unsupportable.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Am I then to understand that in stating that he is here at your express and spontaneous invitation, that he is telling the truth?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Most certainly!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Most unmistakably; I was present when the invitation was given.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: But he tells me that he is here in the capacity of a declared and accepted suitor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (bashfully). So he is!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: You will surely contradict that?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: For the purpose I have in view, I will contradict Mr. Kavanagh in nothing.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: But, great heaven! have you forgotten Guy Warrington? And do you know this man’s character?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (to Denis, who is boiling with indignation). I know, sir, that he is my uncle’s guest, and that in insulting him you have insulted your host, and have insulted me. I insist upon your apologising instantly to Mr. Kavanagh! Instantly, sir – and most amply!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (after a pause). Mr. Kavanagh, it appears that I have been hasty and that I have done you an injustice. I beg your pardon. Miss Blake, I am going on shore, and I need hardly say that I shall not return. I see but too plainly that I can do no good by remaining here – that I am, unfortunately, but an element of discord; in short, that I had better find my way to Gibraltar by another route. (He goes over the side.)

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Scene – Guy’s Quarters at Gibraltar. Druce discovered laying out his master’s mess clothes.

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Well, in this world everything seems to go wrong; here’s my master being a-trotting of himself up and down, between his quarters and the harbour, back’ards and for’ard, any time this last five days to see whether the Skylark with Miss Blake aboard is in sight; and to-day, when she’s signalled, blessed if he ain’t on duty, and can’t leave the barracks. P’raps there’s a world in which everything goes right – a world in which everybody has everythink he wishes for; but it ain’t this one. P’raps it’s as well. I don’t know that it would answer in the army. There’d be too many commanders-in-chief, and not much left for ’em to command. Fancy two hundred thousand field marshals, and, say, one contented rank and file! Lord, how they would re-organize him!

div.stage: Enter Guy, very excited, in patrol jacket.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: She’s here! She’s at anchor in Man-o’-War basin! She’s been at anchor this half-hour and I never knew it. Druce, double down to the harbour – as hard as you can go. Tell them I’m on duty and can’t leave the barracks – and look here – bring them up here – and if they’re not on board they’ll have gone to the hotel – find them, any way. (Exit Druce.) At last – at last! To think that Jessie and I are in the same town again – breathing the same air – cooled by the same sea breeze! It’s a wonderful thought! And in half-an-hour, I shall hold her in my arms – tight! Half-an-hour! She may be here at any moment! It’s too much happiness for one fellow: I must share it with some one. (Calls.) Druce!

div.stage: Enter Druce – livery hat and coat.

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Aren’t you off yet?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Off directly, sir.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Stop! With what description of feelings are you expecting the Skylark?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Description of feelings, sir?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Yes – yes – aren’t you impatient to see her?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: (very stolid). Desperate impatient, sir.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Aren’t you going wild with joy now that’s she’s in harbour?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Wild, sir?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Yes, man; Yes – wild – wild – wild!

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: (stolidly). Wild aren’t the word, sir.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: If I didn’t allow you to go down to the harbour directly, wouldn’t it drive you mad?

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Stark staring mad, sir!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Then off you go, and run like blazes.

sp.speaker: Druce.
sp.p: Like blazes, eh? Blest if I could run like anything else in this here climate. I’m off, sir! (Exit Druce.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: There, I’m better now. Druce is an ass, but it’s better to confide in an ass than in nobody. There she lays! (Looking out of window.) and a rare beauty she is. (Takes telescope.) Perhaps I may be able to twig Jessie with this. (Uses it.) No! There’s nobody on board except the crew. Jessie must be on shore.
