It’s a surprising thing to feel, for the first time in one’s life, that there’s a delightful girl – a real live delightful girl and no deception – at least none to speak of – saving up for you! It’s impossible to realize it now – I suppose I shall get used to it in time, and get to look on Jessie as a matter of course, and shan’t be fidgety whenever she’s out of my sight. Joe Copley, our senior major, is never so jolly as when his wife’s out of his sight! That’s odd; but, then he’s been married five-and-twenty years, and the novelty may have worn off. Oh, Jessie – Jessie, why don’t you come? Why don’t you come? Why don’t you come?

div.stage: Enter Denis.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (gravely). Guy!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: They’re here! Denis! My dear old Den, this is kind of you, to come up to my quarters so soon. Where’s Jessie? Why, what a solemn old phiz! (Alarmed.) There’s nothing the matter. Where is she? She’s quite well?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: There is nothing the matter. She was very well when I saw her last.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: When you saw her last? That can’t be very long since!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Some days – about a week.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: A week!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, I left the yacht at Cadiz, and travelled here by steamer. I was delayed three days at Cadiz, or I should have been here sooner.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: But the yacht’s in harbour. She’s been anchored this half-hour.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Indeed? That’s odd.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: But why did you leave her?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Well, no great matter, perhaps – a question of taste – I didn’t get on very well with Kavanagh.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: No – I should think not (Sits.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (sits). In fact we quarrelled.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Quarrelled? What about?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Well, I’m afraid I was in the wrong, but I don’t like Kavanagh, and I can’t help showing it. I believe I did him an injustice. At all events I had to apologise to him.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: You apologised to that snob?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes; don’t talk of it – change the subject – it’s not a pleasant one. I’m very glad to see you, old fellow.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: There’s something wrong, old man – something more than a row with a fellow like Kavanagh. You are sure Jessie was quite well when you left her?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, quite well.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And happy?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, she seemed so.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Did she know of your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, she knew of it.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And she sided with Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, she sided with Kavanagh.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I’m very sorry for that, very sorry. But you were wrong?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, I was wrong. I made a mistake. Drop the subject.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And you’ve taken care of her? You’ve watched over her? You haven’t let her flirt? She’s been quite true to me?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: My dear Guy, I was true to my trust until I left the yacht; and I should not have left the yacht, even after what had occurred, if I had not been quite sure that my presence on board was no longer necessary.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: True? (Holding out his hand.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Grip! (Taking it.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Thank you, Den. Thank you, and again. Do you know, I began to think at first that there was – that there was something wrong. I can’t tell you how I thank you for your kindness.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (rises). There is little need.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: And, Denis, old man, I expect her here every minute! Think of that! She once said to me that it was worth quarrelling to make it up, as we used to make it up. I say now that it’s worth parting for six weeks to meet each other again, as we shall meet. (Knock.) By Jove, she’s here! (Goes to the door.)
Why, who are you?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: My name’s Grouse, of Grouse and Cookit, attorneys-at-law, of London. Your name’s Warrington?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: That is my name. What do you want?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: It’s business!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Well, go on!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Private and particular. (Nodding at Denis.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Nonsense! I’ve no secrets from this gentleman!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: But I have, a good many! No offence to you, Mr. Grant.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: . Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Oh, yes! I know you. I saw you at Beauclere – also on board the Skylark – just before that unpleasant shindy with Mr. Kavanagh.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (aside to Grouse). Silence, man; not a word to Mr. Warrington about that.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Oh, in course not. Oh, certainly! Oh, to be sure! Mum is the expression. Dumb as an oyster. Oh, yes, not a word about that.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I’ll take a turn in the barrack square, Guy; I shall be close at hand if you want me. (Exit Denis.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Now then, who are you?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I’m a lawyer, sir, of five-and-thirty years’ standing.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Oh! Wouldn’t you like to sit down?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Thank you. (Sits.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Now then, what’s your business?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: It refers to Miss Blake, sir.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Well, go on! She’s quite well?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I humbly trust so, sir; but I didn’t come from her, sir: I come about her. I believe you consider yourself engaged to Miss Blake?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Well, sir?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: And a sweet young couple you’ll make – perhaps! You don’t happen to be an orphan, sir?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: No; I am not.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I’m sorry for that – it’s a pity; but never mind, you will be some day if you’re a good lad.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Nothing, sir; only I’ve come to do you a good turn, and I’d rather you was an orphan on principle. It’s always a pleasure to do a good turn to anybody; but as I used to say to my late missus, the luxuriousness of feeling is increased when one’s dealing with an orphan. She was an orphan, and I’m an orphan.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (quietly). Have you a son?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: (surprised). Yes, sir, I have a son!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Then in about two minutes he’ll be an orphan if you don’t come to the point. Once for all, what is your business with me?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I’m coming to it. Miss Blake’s got a tidy lot of money.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: At least, you think Miss Blake’s got a tidy bit of money.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I know she has property of some kind to which she succeeded on the death of her father.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: That’s it. Miss Blake ain’t Miss Blake. Her father wasn’t her father. Her property ain’t her property. She was his adopted daughter, and he died without a will, so her property belongs to Mr. Kavanagh, the next of kin. At least, that is Mr. Kavanagh’s case, but I know better.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: If Mr. Kavanagh’s statement is true, you can’t suppose that I should counsel Miss Blake to resist his claim.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: No, but it ain’t true. As a general rule, Mr. Kavanagh’s statements never are true. But he’s got two strings to his bow. He intends to prove his case if he can, but he can’t, and he intends to marry Miss Blake if he can’t, and he can. As you’re going to marry her too, I thought you might like to know –

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Mr. Kavanagh is at liberty to intend anything he pleases.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Oh, of course. Only some people object to their wives being married to anybody else but themselves! It’s an amiable weakness, and its amiable character is increased when there’s twelve thousand pounds at stake! Now this is what I propose –

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Why, you infernal scoundrel, Mr. Grant has just told me that –

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I wouldn’t believe Mr. Grant if I was you. I wouldn’t believe anybody if I was you. Except me! Mr. Grant’s an interested party.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Mr. Grant and Mr. Kavanagh had a row at Cadiz.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I know. He told me so.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Yes, but did he tell you what the row was about?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Did you ask him?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: And he declined to tell you?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: He did decline to tell me.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: I thought so. I’ll tell you. It was jealousy.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Ridiculous! When I tell you, sir, that Mr. Grant is my oldest and dearest friend, I have told you enough to show –

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: You have said enough to show that you’re about nineteen years old. My good sir, Mr. Grant proposed to Miss Blake six weeks ago and was rejected by her!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Do you mean to say that you know all this of your own knowledge?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Lord bless you, sir, the row, and the reason of it, was the talk of the whole place. Look here – local English paper – “The Cadiz British Sentinel.” (Reads from paper.) “Fracas on a yacht. An amusing encounter occurred on board the Sk-dash-lark, between Mr. Gr-dash-nt, and Mr. K-dash-v-dash-n-dash-gh, rival suitors for the hand of Miss Bl-dash-ke, a wealthy o-dash-phan. Mr. Gr-dash-nt, left the yacht abruptly, and is travelling by another route to G-dash-b-dash-a-dash-t-dash-r, where he hopes to meet Mr. K-dash v-dash-n-dash-gh. The matter will probably give employment to local gentlemen of the long robe, as the words used by Mr. Gr-dash-nt were undoubtedly act-dash-onable.” Now, sir, allow me to go on with what I’ve come to propose.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Stop! I’ll listen to you presently. This matter must be cleared up first. (Calls at window.) Grant!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: But, sir, you mustn’t mention this or my plan will fail.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, man, and go in there. (Pointing to inner room.)

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: But if Mr. Grant knows of it?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Do as I tell you or I’ll have you kicked out of barracks.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Well, if ever I do a good turn to any but an orphan again, I’m d-dash-mn-dash-d! (Exit Grouse.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (with newspaper). Oh, it must be a lie! and yet his objection to tell me the cause of his quarrel, his leaving the yacht so suddenly, his constrained manner when speaking of Jessie – this newspaper paragraph, everything seems to endorse the scamp’s statement.

div.stage: Enter Denis, Guy stands sternly apart without looking at him.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Well, got rid of him?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (with forced calmness). Yes.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Not a creditor I hope?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Glad of that, old boy.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: He has come to tell me of a creditor.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Creditors are generally ready enough to announce themselves.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: There are creditors, Denis Grant, whose trade is so utterly contemptible that they are ashamed to declare it. My creditor is one of them. There are debts that it is pleasanter to pay than to receive; my debt is one of them.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (after a pause). There is something wrong, Guy!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: There is something wrong, Denis! I’m the victim of a piece of infernal treachery. There is something so wrong that, if the news that fellow has brought me is true, I have placed the whole happiness of my life in the hands of a man who has most shamefully violated that trust.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, this is serious, indeed, my poor Guy! (Taking chair.) Come, old boy, tell me all about it.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Is it necessary to tell you more?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (aside). Poor fellow! he knows the worst!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (bitterly). I see that it is not.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Let us be sure that we understand one another, Guy. Tell me all about it. Who is the man has wronged you, and what was the trust you reposed in him?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: The trust – my love for Jessie Blake! (Denis shows that he expected this.) The man – Denis Grant!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (starting up suddenly). Guy, what in the world do you mean? Are you serious?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Look, and judge for yourself.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: But what do you refer to?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I refer to this: When I left England I begged you to watch over Jessie Blake and protect her. You availed yourself of that trust to endeavour to win her from me. That is what I refer to.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Guy, you are the victim of some monstrous lie!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I am!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Denis Grant, you quarrelled with Kavanagh on board that yacht.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Your quarrel had reference to Miss Blake. (Denis is silent.) I say your quarrel had reference to Miss Blake. Answer me, man, in heaven’s name – and in heaven’s name, say no if you can!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: If you insist on an answer –

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I do insist on an answer.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Then take this one, and be satisfied with it. It had reference to Miss Blake; be wise and ask no more.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I demand a full account of the circumstances of that quarrel.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (after a pause). I cannot give it.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: You refuse?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I refuse.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Then I will supply one. Read that. (Hands newspaper.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (reads). Great heaven! is it possible that you believe this miserable – this preposterous lie?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: That is false!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: It is infamously false, Guy Warrington. Do you know me so little that you have allowed this abominable paragraph to give you more than a moment’s irritation?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: If that is false will you tell me the true story?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (after a pause). No, Guy! I will not! Had I known how little you know of the truth I should not have told you as much as I have. You shall never know the rest from me. It should be sufficient for you that I tell you that this paragraph, based on a certain substratum of truth, is in itself a monstrous and mischievous falsehood!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: It should not be sufficient, because, if you are capable of the villainy here charged against you, you are also capable of covering it with a lie!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: If you know me, you would not think me capable of this villainy.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: It is because I did not know you that I thought you incapable of it. Will you tell me the true story of your quarrel with Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Remember what I have at stake, and in heaven’s name tell me the whole truth.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I can bear it now, whatever it is; it cannot be more bitter than the belief that you have been false to me. Tell me, Denis Grant, for pity’s sake! Den, dear old Den, let me think anything rather than that you have done this fearful thing. Tell me! Tell me all!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: . Then I accept this paragraph as it stands, and so accepting, I tell you that you have behaved like a –

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Stop, you don’t know what you’re doing. Give yourself time to think before you utter another word. I do not ask it for myself. Have mercy on yourself, if you will have none on me! (Taking his hand.) Guy, old fellow, it is not so much that this is hard for me to bear as that it is hard for you to bear. It is not so much that you throw hard words at me, as that you think you have reason to do so. Trust me a little longer. I have borne much for you; bear this for me, until Jessie sets me right with you. Be a man!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Will you tell me the story of your quarrel with Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: No! You shall never hear it from my lips.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (in desperation). What would you have me think? Is my common sense to avail me nothing in dealing with you? Am I to take your word in the face of evidence and evidence that comes cropping up at every turn? Denis Grant, I swear to you that I would give ten years of my life to hear you proved innocent.

div.stage: Enter Kavanagh – he stands irresolutely at door.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: And here is the man who of all others can best place it beyond doubt.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Dear me, I’m afraid my visit is inopportune. Shall I go?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (L.). No, sir; on the contrary, your visit is marvellously well timed. Mr. Kavanagh, this foolish boy has heard of our quarrel on the yacht and attributes it to rivalry for Miss Blake’s hand.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (C.) Well?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I call upon you, sir, to endorse my assurance that I never appeared on board that yacht in the character of Miss Blake’s suitor!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Grant, attend to me. We will assume, if you please for the sake of argument, that I am addressing a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: For heaven’s sake, man, don’t trifle with this unhappy fellow!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Allow me to proceed. At an early stage in your acquaintance with Miss Blake, you propose to marry her. She rejects you.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Stop, in heaven’s name!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: She rejects you perhaps wisely – perhaps foolishly! I think wisely, but then I am no doubt prejudiced. Having a modest faith in the beauty of your own character, you continue your attentions until you find yourself face to face with a successful rival, whom in the heat of the moment you grossly and grievously insult. You discover your mistake, and make under compulsion a formal and unsatisfactory apology, which the presence of ladies compels your rival to accept. Eventually, however, you meet your rival where there are no ladies, and having had time to reflect on your conduct, you offer him an ample and circumstantial apology – not from your lips merely, but from the very bottom of your heart.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: You miserable liar!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: (haughtily). No, no, sir – you forget – I am assuming – for the sake of argument – that you are a gentleman! (Bows and exit, door in flat, R.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Now, sir, what have you to say? Do you deny that you proposed marriage to Miss Blake?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: No; I do not deny that.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: It is quite true? But it was before I knew that you loved her.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Bah! and you never told me of this?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Why should I have told you of it? It would have pained you to hear it – it would have pained me to tell it – it would have pained her to have it told! It would have done much harm and no good.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: It would have done this good, that I should not have entrusted the guardianship of the girl I loved to a rejected suitor. You were bound in honour to tell me.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I was bound in honour to keep a secret which was as much hers as mine. I was further bound in honour never to renew my proposals directly or indirectly, and before heaven, I have kept to my bond.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Before heaven, I don’t believe you.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: It is hard to hear such words from any man, harder from you than any other. When you know the truth, you will never forgive yourself.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: I tell you, sir, that I do not believe you. Do you hear me, Mr. Grant? I say that I do not believe you.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: I hear you!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: You have helped to rob me of my life, in robbing me of my life’s happiness. You have behaved like a scoundrel. Don’t speak, I will not believe one word you say. Do you hear me, sir? Do you hear me? Damn it, man, will nothing rouse you short of this? (Strikes him.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (seizing him and forcing him into a chair). You fool! listen while I tell you what I have done for you. I have devoted myself to your interests, and in protecting them I have made enemies everywhere! I have incurred reproach from Jessie Blake – ridicule from Kavanagh – insult, unspeakable insult from yourself. Go your ways; but take back the word of one who is ten years older in years and twenty in experience – that you will find few friends who will bear for you what Denis Grant has borne – who will take from you what Denis Grant has taken. (Releases him, down, L.)

div.stage: Enter Jessie, Kavanagh, Mrs. Fitzosborne and Boodle, R.

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Guy – dear, dear Guy! Why, won’t you speak to me? It is I – Jessie!

p.stage: (He remains seated with his face covered by his hands.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p:
Miss Blake, I will tell why he won’t speak to you. He believes that my quarrel with Kavanagh, sprung from
motives of jealousy. He refused to believe my denial – he struck me! That blow which nearly drove me out of my senses, seems to have restored him to his. He is sorry and ashamed!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Jessie, what am I to do? What am I to believe?

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: Believe? Believe that I have been wilful, petulant, wicked; believe that I behaved badly to him and to you. Believe anything rather than that Mr. Grant has wronged you. (Crosses, L. C.) Denis Grant, I have no words to express my grief at what has occurred. I have no words that can fitly tell Guy how true you have been to him and to me. But you have a brave and noble nature, and I think you can forgive even me? After all I am only a child! (Denis takes her hand.)

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: But Kavanagh told me –

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: What I believed to be true. I know nothing of the charge you confided to Mr. Grant. I sought Miss Blake’s hand, and I looked at him as a rival.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Then you admit that your statement that you were invited by Miss Blake is –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (R. C.) True, quite true. It’s a dreadful thing to have to say before this gentleman (Indicating Boodle.) and that person (Indicating Kavanagh.) , but – I’ve been the cause of all this – and I advised Jessie to act as she did – and I deserve to be humiliated; and – and I must own, that the invitation to Mr. Kavanagh, was given at my request, and I’m ashamed to say in my behalf. (Crying – Denis goes up, L.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Oh! Mrs. Fitzosborne, I had no idea of this. Why, will you believe me, I thought you disliked me, or I should have made myself much more agreeable. If I had known of this earlier! Why, you could have had no idea at the time that –

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: (sobbing). I could have had no idea at the time that you were an unscrupulous, disreputable, lively, unconscientious, good-looking adventurer. Wasn’t that what you were going to say, Mr. Kavanagh?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Not at all. For once, Mrs. Fitzosborne, you are quite mistaken. (He retires up to Denis.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: Baby, I’ve behaved very badly –

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Well, upon my word, Mrs. Fitz – I think you have!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: I’m very sorry, because I see I’ve pained you; but I’ve had a lesson, and I won’t pain you any more. Could anything be fairer than that? (Sobbing.)

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Nothing could be – I mean no – nothing. (Aside.) Be hanged if she ain’t crying!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: And you forgive me?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: Yeth, I forgive you. (Aside.) I’d no idea thee could cry!

sp.speaker: Mrs. F.
sp.p: I can never forgive myself.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (much affected). Yeth you could, Emily. If you could only thee yourthelf in tearth you’d forgive yourthelf directly!

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Let me make a clean breast of it. Miss Blake, there is a consummate scoundrel who was once a clerk of your late father’s. His name is –

div.stage: Enter Grouse, L.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Grouse – but he ain’t a scoundrel.

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: You here?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: It’th the criminal!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: It’s the lunatic. (Crosses to Boodle.) If ever they get a commission to enquire into the state of your mind, you’d better put your case in my hands, or the other side will subpoena me as a witness, and it’ll be all up with you. Yes, Mr. Kavanagh, I’m here, and in much better health than when we last met. Miss Blake, that person (Indicating Kavanagh.) proposed to me a scheme by which he might dispossess you of your property. In reply, I sent him a letter, repudiating him altogether. That letter he returned to me unopened. Here it is! (Hands envelope to Denis.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (opens letter and reads). “Sir, I have discovered that Miss Blake is an orphan. I cannot consent to assist you in dispossessing an orphan. Apply to a more hardened attorney. There are many of them in the profession. Yours – Anthony Grouse.”

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Do you mean to tell me that that is the identical letter you wrote to me?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: And you returned unopened. The identical one. (Crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Not a copy?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: The identical one. You hear me, sir – the identical one. (Crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: Very good. Oblige me by reading this, Mr. Grant. (Gives copy of letter to Denis.)

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (reads). “Dear Tim.” Who’s dear Tim?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: His partner. That letter was enclosed to me by mistake. Read on.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: “Dear Tim, – old Blake’s will has come to hand. When Kavanagh has touched the money, we’ll try its capacity for further bloodletting. Yours cock-a-doodly, Toney Grouse.”

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Why, what’s that?

sp.speaker: Kavan.
sp.p: That’s a facsimile copy of your letter, taken in my hand press on board the Skylark.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p:
But, I say, you couldn’t have got at my letter, I
tore it into fragments, and threw the pieces overboard It’s a forgery.

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: And that (Pointing to Grouse’s alleged letter.) is the genuine document.

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Quite genuine!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: The identical one?

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: The identical one!

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Which you tore into fragments and threw overboard? Mr. Grouse, this time you appear to have overreached yourself.

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: (to Grouse). I thay, when you get committed at the Old Bailey, you’d better get me out of the way, or the other side will thubpoena me as a witness, and it’ll be all up with you. (Aside.) Nothing could be fairer than that!

sp.speaker: Grouse.
sp.p: Why, what’ll you swear?

sp.speaker: Boodle.
sp.p: What’ll I thwear? Why, I’ll thwear Grouthe ith black game, and back my opinion at any oddth the prethent company like to name. No takerth! Nothing can be fairer than that!

sp.speaker: Jessie.
sp.p: (to Guy, who is seated at table, with his head buried in his hands). Guy, dear Guy! I have not been as bad as you think! I am a flirt, and I can’t help it! Can you forgive me?

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: What have I to forgive! (Turning to Denis.) Denis – my dear old Den – I – I’m a gentleman by position, and I’ve behaved like a snob! I can’t put it harder than that! – if I could I would. I – I – are you going to cut me for it?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Cut you! My dear boy, a mere acquaintance could do no more.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: Then you forgive me?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: A mere friend could do no less!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: But really! –

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: Yes, really!

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.p: (offering hand). True?

sp.speaker: Denis.
sp.p: (taking it). Grip!

div.stage: Curtain.
